banner.title: TP WorkLife 10/12
banner.mainContentHeadline: The podcast where science meets business
banner.mainContent: From fixing meetings to finding a mentor, get new insights to help you enjoy your time at work and thrive in your career.

videoData.title: A call to end the media coverage mass shooters want
videoData.socialTitle: A call to end the media coverage mass shooters want

takeAction.blurb: When you see any media organization gratuitously using the names and images of mass shooters -- **stop** watching, listening, clicking, liking and sharing. **Write** to the producers, editors and station managers. Take note of which advertisers supported a segment, write to their CEOs and **speak out** on social media. Because together, we can push the media to act in the interest of public safety, not profits.

nodes.description: Co-founder of the No Notoriety campaign
nodes.whoTheyAre: Tom Teves urges the leadership of news organizations to find better ways to inform the public about mass shootings that puts safety before profits.
nodes.whyListen:
Tom and Caren Teves faced every parent’s worst nightmare: Their oldest-born son, Alex, was killed shielding his girlfriend during a mass shooting on July 20, 2012 inside an Aurora, Colorado, theater.
 
The senseless murder of their son prompted the Teves’ to try to stop this from happening to any other family. They began research into the motivation that leads someone to walk into a movie theater, church or school and want to kill random people.
 
What they found is that the data was complicated, but surprising clear. The single, greatest motivating factor that all of these murderers had in common was the desire to become famous, to be noticed. The Teves immediately started working to educate the media so that news organizations would understand that if they could remove the motivational factor, they would take away the shooter’s self-perceived “reward” of notoriety.
 
After eight long years, many media entities have changed but others still continue to let profits take priority over responsibility, common sense and safety. 
 
Join the Teves in helping get the media to stop making anti-heroes of these murderers.

videoData.description: On July 20, 2012, a mass shooting in a movie theater of Aurora, Colorado left the town, and its nation, reeling. To many -- including Tom Teves, who lost his son in the tragedy -- the news coverage that followed focused on all the wrong things. Why did the reporting overwhelmingly fixate on the shooter rather than the lives of the victims or the heroic efforts of first responders? With urgency and measure, Teves calls for responsible media attention that acts in the interest of the public (instead of profit) by revoking what shooters want most: infamy.
videoData.socialDescription: On July 20, 2012, a mass shooting in a movie theater of Aurora, Colorado left the town, and its nation, reeling. It's my son Alex's girlfriend, Amanda,
and they dragged me out of the theater.

I wanted to [stay],
but they dragged me out."
"Amanda, are you OK? Have you been hurt?"
And she said no, that she was fine,
that Alex had saved her life.
"I don't know, we can't find him.
They dragged me out of the theater.

I tried to wake him up,
but I couldn't wake him up.

They dragged me away.
I didn't want to leave him."
Did you have any of his blood on you?"

And he was one of the most
honorable men on earth,

he had to make the decision
to risk his life
in order to ensure she would live.
I knew in my heart if he couldn't get up,
for a week's vacation in Hawaii.

Caren and I frantically started
calling his cell phone,
We then turned to the media.

We tried calling
the Aurora police station,
but it was impossible to get an answer.
But in hindsight, it was understandable.

the police had to bring
some of the victims to the hospitals
in the backs of their police cars,
because they had run out of ambulances.
It was a horrific and chaotic scene.
We would never see Alex again,
I had to shield even his mom

for fear that would be
the lasting image of him in her mind.

But you know who we would see
again and again?
One article was six paragraphs long
The media had made him famous.
was absent from those initial reports.

Caren and I immediately realized
that there was something wrong

with the way the media responds
to these random mass shootings
we could reduce the amount of shootings

these murderers

and their number of kills.

and then stopped to check Facebook

The Aurora theater murderer

about a previous mass murderer,
but when they spill a little blood,
the whole world knows who they are."

A man who was known by no one
is now known by everyone,
his face splashed across every screen,
It seems like the more people you kill,
the more you're in the limelight.
These are just a few examples.
I could go on and on.

These murderers are telling us
they want to be famous

and the media continues to give them
exactly what they seek:
The gun debate is very emotional,

and our mental health issues
are very complicated.
Both will take time to correct.
we don't need an act of Congress.
What we need is an act of conscience

on the producers
and consumers of mass media
to remove the reward of notoriety.

by adhering to these

any self-serving material

to leverage guidelines
they already have in place.
on journalists that have been kidnapped
of victims of sexual assault or suicide.
on the public's right to know.

the media should elevate

They won't change unless

based on the number of viewers and clicks.

the media will change

So the next time you see

gratuitously leveraging the names

Take note of the advertisers

we can push the media

and it's too late for my family.

But please don't join

for people who aren't victims yet.

footnotes.annotation:
> "The media does not report the names and images of victims of sexual assault or suicide."

[Many news organizations](https://www.ndhealth.gov/injury/ND_Prevention_Tool_Kit/docs/2013MediaManual.pdf) have adopted a policy of not identifying victims of sexual assault, unless the victim is willing to speak publicly. [Following the recommendations of experts in suicide prevention](https://reportingonsuicide.org/recommendations/), some news organizations have also adopted policies to withhold details of suicides.

> "Academic studies show that the average news consumer wants to hear less about the shooters."

According to a 2018 study that analyzed a sample of news consumers, [approximately 60 percent of respondents](https://cdn.ymaws.com/www.acjs.org/resource/resmgr/Abstracts_for_Web_1-4-18.pdf) reported that they would still follow coverage of mass shootings even if the perpetrators' names and images were minimized.

> "All the experts agree. The FBI, the International Police Association, the Major City Chiefs Association and A.L.E.R.T., the law enforcement organization dedicated to training first responders to stop active shooters, all endorse the principles of No Notoriety."

In addition to [the official endorsements](https://nonotoriety.com/data-%e2%80%a2-experts/) made by the International Police Association and The Major Cities Chiefs, No Notoriety also works alongside the ["Don't Name Them" campaign](https://www.dontnamethem.org/), a similar proposal developed by the FBI in conjunction with [the Advanced Law Enforcement Rapid Response Training program](http://www.alerrt.org/) at Texas State University and the [I Love U Guys Foundation](http://iloveuguys.org/).

> "The American Psychiatric Association supports reducing and minimizing the identification of these shooters."

Correction: A psychologist [who presented her paper](https://www.apa.org/news/press/releases/2016/08/media-contagion) at the American Psychological Association's 2016 annual convention, reported that "media contagion" is a factor in mass shootings and called on the media to withhold shooters' names.

> "Almost every single random mass shooter has something in common. Can anybody guess what that is? They want notoriety. They want to be famous."

[According to a 2020 study](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/1745-9133.12472), more recent public mass shootings adhere to a consistent profile in which perpetrators sought fame, were often directly influenced by previous attackers, had planned their attacks for more than a year, and, in most cases, had developed a specific attack strategy to kill more victims. Differentiated from other mass shooters by their explicit desire for infamy, recent scholarship has introduced fame-seeking perpetrators as a new type of mass shooter.

> "The Parkland murderer recorded and posted a video stating, 'When you see me on the news, you'll know who I am.'"

Clarification: While the Parkland shooter did record 3 videos on his cellphone, he did not post them; [they were released to the public](https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/30/us/nikolas-cruz-parkland-video.html) by the Broward State Attorney’s Office.

> "For example, the media does not report on journalists that have been kidnapped in order to protect them."

While news blackouts have become [a well-established tradition](https://archives.cjr.org/behind_the_news/journos_and_kidnapping.php) among American news organizations, particularly when a journalist is kidnapped by captors seeking ransom, [there has been increased debate](https://archives.cjr.org/the_kicker/james_foley_steven_sotloff_media_blackout.php) about whether they are actually an effective strategy.
